key_points: Cyber Command, the US militaryâ€™s hacking unit, has taken offensive action to disrupt ransomware attacks targeting US companies.
The specific actions taken by Cyber Command were not disclosed.
This move marks one of the first clear acknowledgments of targeting cybercriminal groups since the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack in May.
Gen. Paul Nakasone, head of Cyber Command and director of the NSA, indicated a shift towards hacking criminal groups, not just state actors.
US security agencies have increased efforts against ransomware groups following significant attacks on the Colonial Pipeline and a major meat processor.
A 'surge' against ransomware operators aimed at cutting off their funding has been conducted, as stated by Nakasone.
The US government's counteroffensive includes indicting extortionists and sanctioning a cryptocurrency exchange for laundering money for hackers.
The White House is pushing the Russian government to act against cybercriminals based in Russia.
President Biden is set to discuss cybersecurity in an upcoming video call with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
The focus on cybersecurity follows Biden urging Putin to tackle hacker activities during a meeting in Geneva six months ago.
spokespersons: Gen. Paul Nakasone (Head of Cyber Command and Director of the National Security Agency)
